awd_titl_txt: Comprehensive Study of 3D Magnetosphere-Ionospheric Current System Through the  Modeling, Observations, and Applications: Auroral Electrojet Indices for the Southern Hemisphere
awd_abstract_narration:
The Earth's three-dimensional magnetosphere-ionosphere current system is an important component of the Geospace environment. These currents are driven by the interaction of solar wind (an everlasting plasma flow from the Sun) with the Earth's magnetosphere, transferring significant amounts of energy and momentum into the high-latitude ionosphere and upper atmosphere via the geomagnetic field-aligned currents. The 3D current system dynamics affect both the Northern and South Polar Regions, causing their dynamic changes and heating through the closure of these currents in the Earth's ionosphere. These currents can be modeled, but they are difficult to observe from the ground or even from space - only their effects on geomagnetic field variations (and respective indices of geomagnetic activity) can be recorded by properly placed ground-based instruments. 

This award will support a study of a relatively unexplored phenomenon of interhemispheric field-aligned currents through the model development and comparison of modeled results with the ground-based and satellites observations. This new model will significantly advance our understanding of the physics of space weather-driving processes in both hemispheres and development of an index describing geomagnetic activities in the Southern polar region. The latter is important because calculating this index using existing Aural Electrojet (AE) technique (that uses data from 12 geomagnetic observatories across the Northern auroral region) is not applicable to the Southern auroral region that goes over Southern Ocean for ~50% of the global coverage. There are only 5-6 Antarctic costal research stations that can contribute to this index calculations, which is much less than optimal for the traditional AE calculation technique. This research effort has the potential to significantly increase our understanding of the role played by interhemispheric currents on the dynamics of the polar and auroral regions.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Over the past year, we successfully finalized the development and enhancement of the L-2015 magnetosphere-ionospheric current system model. This effort included the integration of diverse solar wind conditions, resulting in a model that closely mirrors observed data.

During this period, we discovered critical shortcomings in our model that impacted its performance. After a detailed investigation into the sources of these weaknesses, we implemented significant improvements to address them. These improvements resulted in a more robust and reliable model. A key improvement in this version is the inclusion of the substorm current wedge as a new factor. This means the model now takes into account all the major factors that influence the features and dynamics of the ionosphere-magnetosphere current system.

As a result, the refined model has demonstrated significantly improved accuracy and reliability, providing more dependable results. These refinements not only resolved the initial limitations but also advanced our understanding and capability in modeling the magnetosphere-ionospheric current system.

We compared our L-2015 model's outputs with real-world observations from ground-based magnetometers included in the SuperMAG data collection system and satellite-based instruments like AMPERE (see attached figures) to verify its reliability. These comparisons showed that our model's results accurately reproduce real-world data, marking a substantial improvement in our understanding and simulation of magnetosphere-ionospheric dynamics.

We also made progress on the Polar Magnetic index, undertaking a comprehensive modification and recalculation process spanning 11 years of data (from 2010 to 2020). This revised version, now termed the Modified Polar Magnetic (MP) index, was adjusted to better fit the empirical data.

Our approach involved refining the index to enhance its accuracy and relevance in reflecting the observed magnetic variations. To ensure the robustness and reliability of the MP index, we conducted a thorough verification process. This included analyzing its correlation with solar wind data, which confirmed that the modifications resulted in a more precise and dependable index.

Our work involves continuous collaboration with two geomagnetic stations situated near the geomagnetic poles: DOME-C in Antarctica and Qaanaaq (also known as Thule) in the Arctic region. We also calculated this index based on data from the Vostok station in Antarctica for the years when the data was available.

Additionally, our work focused on finding a reliable substitute for AE indices for the Southern Hemisphere. The Auroral Electrojet (AE) indices, which include the Auroral Upper (AU) and Lower (AL) indices, are valuable indicators of geomagnetic activity. These indices measure the intensity of eastward and westward auroral electrojets, respectively, in the polar ionospheres. They are designed to assess the strength of these electrojets and are considered the best indicators of geomagnetic storms and substorms.

However, AE indices measurement is largely confined to the Northern Hemisphere, due to challenges in collecting data from the Southern Hemisphere. An accurate AE calculation needs a dozen stations equally spaced around an auroral oval, a requirement difficult to meet in the Southern Hemisphere because of a lack of land-based geomagnetic observatories. This deficiency stems from the auroral oval's oceanic positioning and logistical difficulties in maintaining Antarctic geomagnetic stations. Thus, precise Southern Hemisphere AL and AU indices are hard to obtain.

To mitigate this, our study uses data from a single geomagnetic station near the geomagnetic pole in each hemisphere. We use magnetic data from Qaanaaq, Greenland, and Dome-C, Antarctica, for the Northern and Southern Hemispheres, respectively.

We've developed a method offering close approximations for both AU and AL indices. This approach uses data from these specific geomagnetic stations and outcomes from our L-2015 ionospheric electrodynamics model. Without considering solar activity, these indices correlate with Northern Hemisphere's AL and AU indices with the coefficient 0.82. This correlation rises to 0.88 when we account for solar cycle development. We continue to improve this method.

This novel method is pivotal in enhancing our understanding of space weather dynamics. It enables us to derive accurate AU and AL indices approximations in the Southern Hemisphere, where direct measurements are traditionally challenging. Given these indices' significant correlation with space weather phenomena, this new method bolsters our predictive and responsive capabilities regarding space weather changes. It could enhance our forecasting abilities for events with potential impacts on Earth's infrastructure, such as geomagnetic storms. Hence, these new proxy AE indices mark a crucial advance in our ongoing efforts to better comprehend, predict, and mitigate space weather effects.

We presented the results of our research at the AGU Fall 2023 conference and will be presenting them again at the AGU Fall 2024 conference in December.
